questions.question: Which of the following are not risk factors for developing gestational diabetes?
You discover that there is evidence of cardiac malformation in a fetus during a routine USGscan at 16 weeks. What is the minimum level of fasting blood sugar at which you can suspectovert diabetes?
questions.explanation: Overt diabetes is when fasting blood sugar is ≥ 126 mg/dl. Overt diabetics are women who areknown to have diabetes before pregnancy.A patient is said to have overt diabetes if:• Fasting blood sugar ≥ 126 mg/dL• A random blood sugar of ≥ 200 mg/dL• HbA1c of ≥ 6.5%The maternal complication of diabetes:•⚫ increased Miscarriage and preterm labor.• increased incidence of preeclampsia••polyhydramniosprolongation of labor due to shoulder dystocia, operative interference, and cephalo-pelvicdisproportion.Fetal and Neonatal complications of diabetes:•fetal macrosomia (birth weight > 4kg)496•congenital malformations - Musculoskeletal, urogenital, and CNS anomalies.

questions.question: A patient underwent a one-step procedure for gestational diabetes screening. Which of thefollowing statements regarding this procedure is false?

options.A: Fasting blood glucose > 92 mg/dL is diagnostic
options.B: 100 grams of glucose is given after overnight fast

questions.explanation: In one-step procedure, the patient is given 75g of glucose after an overnight fast, and bloodglucose is measured hourly for 2 hours.Diagnostic criteria with one-step procedure is as follows:•Fasting ≥ 92 mg/dL•●1-hour ≥ 180 mg/dL2-hour ≥ 153 mg/dLIn two-step approach patient is given glucose and subsequent values measured in two separatesteps.•Step 1 - the patient is given 50 grams of glucose and blood glucose is measured after one hour. Ifit is ≥140 mg/dl then the screen is positive and step 2 is done.•Step 2 - the patient is given 100g of glucose and values measured hourly, for 3 hours. A diagnosisis made if at least two values are high using one of two methods.DIPSI (Diabetes In Pregnancy Societies of India) recommends a one-step procedure withoutregard to the time of the last meal. Here the patient is given 75 grams of oral glucose. A bloodglucose value of ≥140 mg/dL after 2-hours is diagnostic.

questions.question: A woman at 28 weeks of gestation is started on insulin therapy after being diagnosed withgestational diabetes mellitus. What should be the fasting blood glucose target in her?490
questions.explanation: The target fasting blood glucose level in a patient with gestational diabetes mellitus is 95 mg/dl.In gestational diabetes mellitus, the targets are:Fasting ≤ 95 mg/dl• 1-h postprandial ≤ 140 mg/dl• 2-h postprandial ≤ 120 mg/dl•• HbA1c ≤ 6.0%.

Other than A1, all the other classes are managed by insulintherapy.Priscilla White's classification for diabetes in pregnancy is not used anymore. questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of hyperglycemiaduring pregnancy?

options.A: Metformin crosses the placenta and has teratogenic effects on the fetus
options.B: Diet control is the first line management
options.C: HbA1c monitored at the end of the first trimester and then every 3 months thereafter
options.D: Insulin is the first line pharmacological agent

questions.explanation: Metformin crosses the placenta. However, no teratogenic effects have been observed as yet.Insulin is the preferred treatment in gestational diabetes mellitus because it does not cross theplacenta (American Diabetes Association).Management of diabetes in pregnancy:• Preconceptional counseling:• To achieve tight control of diabetes before the onset of pregnancy.• HbA1c level measured to plan pregnancy..• Appropriate advice about diet and insulin given• Antenatal care (at monthly intervals up to 20 weeks and thereafter at 2 weeks intervals):• Diabetic diet-30 Kcal/kg for normal BMI, 24 Kcal/kg for overweight women, and 12 kcal/kg formorbidly obese women• Frequent monitoring of blood glucose• HbA1c determination at the end of the first trimester and then every 3 months thereafter. HbA1clevel of ≤6% is desirable• Insulin therapy - initiated when diabetes is not controlled by diet alone• Oral hypoglycemic drugs- glibenclamide and metformin are safe.

questions.question: A primigravida on screening was found to have a fasting blood glucose of more than 100mg/dl. Which of the following medications will you not prescribe to her?
questions.explanation: Tolbutamide is not used for the treatment of gestational diabetes.498First-generation sulfonylureas such as tolbutamide and chlorpropamide can cause teratogenicity,neonatal hypoglycemia, and fetal hyperinsulinemia.First-line glycemic control agents in pregnancy:• Insulin• Glyburide• Metformin

questions.question: 491A primigravida at 30 weeks of gestation is admitted with preterm labour contractions. Shewas diagnosed with gestational diabetes, on screening. Which of the following tocolytic drugsshould be avoided in her?
questions.explanation: Terbutaline should be avoided in pregnant women with diabetes.Terbutaline (ẞ-mimetic drugs) given for tocolysis can cause hyperglycemia, which can causediabetic ketoacidosis. Factors precipitating ketoacidosis in pregnancy:•Hyperemesis gravidarum• Infection• Non-compliance• Insulin pump failure• ẞ-sympathomimetic drugs• Corticosteroids• Poor glycemic control

questions.question: According to the American college of obstetricians, macrosomia is defined as the fetal birthweight of
questions.explanation: According to the American college of obstetricians (ACOG), macrosomia is defined as the fetalbirth weight of ≥ 4.5 kg.Macrosomia refers to growth beyond a specific threshold, regardless of gestational age. Indeveloped countries, the most commonly used threshold is the weight above 4.5 kg, but weightabove 4 kg is also commonly used.The WHO defines the cut-off at 4.0 kg for fetal macrosomia in its guidelines for the managementof common maternal conditions. This is followed in India.

questions.question: In gestational diabetes, which of the following is an independent and substantial risk factorfor macrosomia?
questions.explanation: BMI (body mass index) is an independent and substantial risk factor for macrosomia in bothdiabetic and non-diabetic mothers.BMI levels are associated with increased birth weight, regardless of glucose levels. Gestationaldiabetes prevalence increases by approximately 1 percent for every 1 kg/m2 increase in BMI.499BMI cutoffs for pregnancy:-Underweight < 18 kg/m2Normal 18.5 to 24.9 kg/m2Overweight - 25 to 29.9 kg/m2Obese >30 kg/m2-Weight distribution also seems to play a role because the risk of gestational diabetes is increasedwith truncal obesity. HbA1c levels are associated with fetal malformations in pre-gestationaldiabetes.

questions.question: According to ACOG, routine cesarean delivery is advocated in a woman with gestationaldiabetes mellitus if the sonographically estimated fetal weight isg.
questions.explanation: According to the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG), routine cesareandelivery is advocated in a woman with gestational diabetes mellitus if the sonographicallyestimated fetal weight is ≥ 4500 g.

questions.question: A pregnant woman has gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) and her blood glucose levels arewell controlled on insulin. What will be the appropriate gestational age for her delivery?
questions.explanation: The most appropriate time for the delivery in this patient would be 39 weeks as she has goodglycemic control with insulin.The timing for delivery in a pregnant woman with GDM would vary depending on the control ofglucose levels & mode of treatment.Appropriate timing for delivery in gestational diabetesWell-controlledwith diet39 weeks to 40 weeks +6 daySWell-controlledwithinsulin/or 39 weeks to 39 weeks + 6 dayal agentCo-morbidityor suboptimal controlWithpoor glycemic controlSInduction before 39 weeksReasonable to deliver at 37 to38 weeks + 6 days of gestationIn extreme cases where allefforts for glycemic control have failed induction prior to37 weeks (no clear cut guideline)

questions.question: Which of the following complications is unlikely in a patient with gestational diabetes?
questions.explanation: 500Polyhydramnios is a complication of diabetes, not oligohydramnios.Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) is commonly defined as glucose intolerance first recognizedduring pregnancy.Complications of gestational diabetes:•••Spontaneous abortionPreterm laborUnexplained fetal demise• Hypoglycemia• Malformations• Altered fetal growth.• Hypocalcemia• Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy• Pre-eclampsia•Respiratory distress syndrome• Polyhydramnios

questions.question: On screening, a primigravida is found to have fasting blood glucose of 110mg/dl. What is thelikelihood that she will develop overt diabetes within the next 20 years?
questions.explanation: 50 % of women with gestational diabetes develop overt diabetes within 20 years. Hence, they arerecommended to undergo screening and revaluation from time to time.Fasting blood glucose of ≥ 92 mg/dL indicates gestational diabetes.

questions.question: A 29-year-old woman with overt diabetes comes to you for pre-conception counseling. Whichof the following congenital heart defects are least likely to occur if she were to have a child?
questions.explanation: Tetrology of Fallot (TOF) is usually not seen in infants of diabetic mothers.Ventricular septal defect and transposition of great arteries are the most common cardiacanomalies in infants of diabetic mothers.Cardiac defects that present more often in infants of diabetic mothers are:•Transposition of the great arteries (TGA)• Double outlet right ventricle (DORV)• Ventricular septal defect (VSD)• Truncus arteriosus•Tricuspid atresia•• Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)501The most common cardiac anomaly in an infant of a diabetic mother is a controversial topic. Mostresources mention VSD and TGA are the most common and do not specify which among them ismore common.

questions.question: Hypocalcemia in a newborn is defined as serum calcium
questions.explanation: Hypocalcemia in a newborn is defined as serum calcium < 8 mg/dl.Hypocalcemia is one of the potential metabolic derangements in neonates of diabetic mothers.There is hypomagnesemia in the mother and the infant due to increased maternal urinaryexcretion of magnesium due to diabetes. There is maternal hyperparathyroidism due tohypomagnesemia which leads to increased maternal calcium.This maternal calcium passes to the infant through the placenta and suppresses fetal PTHsynthesis and impairs PTH response to postpartum hypocalcemia. PTH suppression, in this case,can be severe and lead to convulsions in the early neonatal period and may persist for months.

questions.question: You are performing capillary blood glucose charting for newborns in the post-natal ward.Below what level is it considered hypoglycemia?
questions.explanation: Neonatal hypoglycemia is defined as blood glucose levels <45 mg/dL.Maternal hyperglycemia stimulates the fetal pancreas to secrete excess insulin, which causesincreased neonatal fat deposition, abdominal girth, and macrosomia (Pederson's hypothesis). Italso leads to a rapid drop in plasma glucose concentration after delivery.

questions.question: Identify the maternal condition that can lead to the findings in the baby as shown below.494
questions.explanation: The image showing a poorly developed lower limb suggests the diagnosis of caudal regressionsequence/sacral agenesis seen in pregestational diabetes. It is the most specific anomaly seen indiabetes.The caudal regression sequence is a rare malformation, frequently associated with maternalpre-gestational diabetes. It consists of a spectrum of structural defects of the caudal region,including incomplete development of the sacrum and the lumbar vertebrae.Elevated maternal HbA1c levels correlate with fetal malformations. It occurs approximately 200times more frequently in infants of diabetic mothers than in other infants.Overt diabetes (pregestational diabetes) is associated with higher malformation rates than thegeneral population. Neural tube defects (encephalocele, meningomyelocele, anencephaly),transposition of great vessels, ventricular septal defect, atrial septal defect, hypoplastic left heart,aortic stenosis and coarctation of the aorta are commonly seen.Small left colon syndrome is a rare anomaly that develops in the second and third trimesters.Option B: Malformations are not associated with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM).Malformations occur due to the disruption of organogenesis, usually occurring in the first502trimester. The abnormal glycemic status in GDM manifests only in the second trimester.Option C: Valproate leads to neural tube defects and not sacral agenesis.Option D: ACE inhibitors can cause oligohydramnios.

questions.question: Which of the following will be the most effective contraception in a female with hypertensionand a history of gestational diabetes mellitus?
questions.explanation: Intrauterine devices are the most effective contraceptive choice in patients with gestationaldiabetes mellitus and hypertension.It is suitable in patients with diabetes and comorbidities like obesity, hypertension, ordyslipidemia. It is a method without potential cardiovascular consequences, unlike hormonalcontraceptives.Low-dose hormonal contraceptives can be used safely in women with gestational diabetes if thereare no associated comorbidities.Even though the barrier method will not lead to complications in such patients, the failure rate ishigh due to incorrect use and non-compliance. Hence it is not preferred.Option D: DMPA(depot-medroxyprogesterone acetate) is an injectable hormonal contraceptivethat is contraindicated in diabetic pregnant women with co-morbidities.503
